text:
INTERVIEWER:
Hi.

Can you tell us your names and
what course you teach?

LERMAN: I'm Steve Lerman.
HARWARD: And I am Judd Harward.

LERMAN: And we teach course
1.00 which in MIT is

Introduction to computation and
engineering problem solving.

INTERVIEWER:
And can you tell us what are

the goals of this particular
class?

LERMAN: The course is designed
for students who are not

majoring in computer science but
need to have a basic

comprehension of computational
methods and computer

programming.
So we draw students from all

the departments of MIT.
Even once in a while a computer

science major takes the course.
So our goals are to teach

students about computing,
teach them a programming

language, and introduce them to
some introductory algorithms in

several different areas.
INTERVIEWER:

So what happens on a daily
basis in class?

HARWARD: We used to teach it as
a standard lecture and problem

set course, but we found that
many of the students would delay

until the night before the
problem set to really come to

grips with the material,
often in the wee hours of the

morning.
And so, inspired by colleagues

in physics, we tried to
incorporate active learning

techniques in the course.
So, in an average week,

we will have one to two
standard lectures.

But we will also have at least
one session where,

after presenting the material,
we then ask the students to

work through a problem,
while we are available,

to answer questions.
And the TAs in the course

circulate, too.
And, in working out the

problem, very often that
involves programming.

So we have introduced the use
of laptops in class.

INTERVIEWER:
So is a small group type of

structure then?
Or how does the lecture versus

the small group aspect of it
work?

LERMAN: Well,
both those activities take

place in a lecture style hall
but the students are doing very

different things.
In lecture, it is very

traditional.
One of us is in front of the

class for sustained periods of
time teaching the students.

In the active learning,
we typically pose a problem.

And those of you who look at
the Open Courseware site will

see notes where we switched to
that mode.

And the students are solving
guided problems.

And then Judd and I and our
teaching assistants are

wandering around the room
looking over people's shoulders

and helping them get through the
guided exercises.

And then we will talk about
them.

We will reassemble everybody in
more a lecture style to have a

discussion about what that
assignment was about.

And that might go back and
forth several times within a

course of an active learning
session.

INTERVIEWER:
So how are students assessed in

this area?
Is it mostly on their coding

assignments?
Are there also exams and

quizzes?
Or can you say more about that?

HARWARD: There are exams and
quizzes, but nobody programs

best under pressure.
So the problem sets,

we feel, are a more reliable
means of assessing the students.

And, actually,
we think a lot of the learning

in the course comes from working
through those problem sets.

So, by the end of the course,
we actually combine two problem

sets over two or three weeks
where we ask the students in the

first problem set to plan a much
more major assignment.

And we pair them up so they are
working in teams.

And then they code their own
design for the final problem set

of the course.
INTERVIEWER:

And what size teams would they
be working in?

LERMAN: We usually use teams of
two.

It is always a tradeoff.
Larger teams could do bigger

projects.
But then the logistics,

particularly at the end of a
busy semester of the students

getting together to cooperate,
turn out to be complicated.

So we have decided on teams of
two.

Occasionally,
we will have a team of three

or, in some rare cases someone
will just do the assignment on

his or her own.
HARWARD: Actually,

the undergraduates in
management who were taught to

work in teams,
they sometimes ask to work in

teams of three because they are
used to it.

INTERVIEWER:
Now, are there any other

special course elements such as
fieldtrips or guest lecturers or

anything like that that you
incorporate?

LERMAN: No.
The course is,

in that sense,
pretty traditional.

Most of the activities happen
either in class.

We do have tutorial sessions.
So, in addition to four to five

hours of in-class time with one
of us, the teaching assistants

take small groups,
usually ten to twelve students

and spend an hour a week in a
much more interactive style

where they can talk much more
closer to one-on-one.

And then we all have extensive
office hours where we meet

individually with students.
HARWARD: If there is a problem

set that the students
particularly enjoyed,

sometimes we have a
competition.

We had them program The Game of
Life a couple of years ago,

and we had a competition to see
who could add the most

interesting features to the
game.

INTERVIEWER:
Now, is there anything else

that is sort of unique or
special about the class that you

haven't talked about so far?
LERMAN: Well,

we are part of a group of
courses at MIT that are

experimenting with laptops in
the classroom.

Right now MIT does not have a
laptop requirements so all

students don't have laptops.
Many do, of course,

a growing fraction buy them on
their own.

So we ask those who have them
to bring them to class.

We loan students,
who don't have them,

laptops.
And many of the exercises

require using the laptop in the
class, and as well as being used

outside the class.
INTERVIEWER:

OK.
Any final thoughts?

LERMAN: Well,
one thing to emphasize about

this course is while right now
we teach it in the Java language

and the Open Courseware site
reflects the notes,

we have actually taught it over
time in many different

languages.
A central element of the course

is it really isn't about the
programming language.

They learn the programming
language, but it is really about

algorithmic design,
reusable code modules,

the notion of object-oriented
programming.

And I personally have taught it
in, I think, four or five

different languages over the
last 25 years.

INTERVIEWER:
OK.

Well, thank you very much for
participating in Open

Courseware.
We really appreciate your

input.
HARWARD: Thank you.
LERMAN: Thank you.
